summary: The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of West Virginia today entered a final judgment in favor of Turner Construction Company v. Modern Mosaic Ltd., a firm specializing in precast concrete.  According to the court's order, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) entered into a contract (the “Prime Contract”) to construct a parking garage at the FBI facility in West Virginia.  The Prime Contract required that Modern construct pre-cast concrete panels on an existing parking garage.  As alleged in the complaint, however, that the Prime Contract did not require Modern to field verify the structure.  Rather, the complaint alleges that Modern fabricated the panels at its own risk because of the deficient soil remediation work of another subcontractor.  In addition, the court found that Turner violated the duty of good faith and fair dealing when it settled with the FBI.   The court also ruled that Turner should be estopped from denying Modern’s claims because of its improper conduct regarding a mediation between the FBI and Turner following the completion of the project.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the court order, Turner consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay $975,072.31 in disgorgement and prejudgment interest, and to pay a civil penalty of $100,000.  Additionally, Turner agreed to be barred from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security deposit in connection with the purchase of a security deposit.  To settle the case, Turner also agreed to pay civil penalties of $150,000 and $75,000, respectively, in the amount of $1 million.  Turner agreed not to participate in the purchase, sale, offer and sale of security deposit, or any other security deposit as part of his or her obligation to the FBI as a matter of law.  Finally, the settlement is subject to court approval.
